\n The Bellman-Ford algorithm is a single-source shortest path algorithm that computes the shortest paths from a single source vertex to all other vertices in a weighted directed graph.\n

\n

  • Can handle graphs with negative edge weights

\n Named after Richard Bellman and Lester Ford Jr., this algorithm was developed in the 1950s and 1960s. \n It's particularly important in network routing and distributed systems where negative weights can represent \n costs, delays, or other metrics that need to be minimized.\n

\n
\n

\n

\n
3

The Bellman-Ford algorithm is a single-source shortest path algorithm that computes the shortest paths from a single source vertex to all other vertices in a weighted directed graph.

Algorithm Steps:

Initialization: Set distance to source vertex as 0 and all other vertices as infinity (∞)
